questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of acute-onset vertigo that has lasted for two days. She has had a viral upper respiratory tract infection for the past 3 days and yesterday she started feeling off-balance with the sensation of the room-spinning and muffled hearing on the right. She has associated nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is noncontributory. Medications include over-the-counter decongestants. temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Examination reveals left-beating horizontal nystagmus with all extraocular eye movements. She develops catch-up saccades with rightward rotation of the head. A cover/uncover test of the eyes is normal. External and middle ear examinations are within normal limits bilaterally. gait is ataxic. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent, new-onset vertigo, associated with muffled hearing on the right, nausea, and gait impairment. The positive head impulse test, direction-fixed horizontal nystagmus away from the affected side, and the absence of vertical skew support a peripheral vestibular syndrome (i.e. labyrinthitis or vestibular neuritis) Decreased hearing on the right noted by the finger rub test would suggest a diagnosis of labyrinthitis, and not vestibular neuritis which is no not associated with hearing loss. The acute onset of vertigo with nausea, vomiting, and gait impairment. Unilateral hearing loss following an upper respiratory illness is consistent with labyrinthitis.        

In Patients with persistent, new-onset vertigo, who have a negative head impulse test with direction-changing (horizontal/vertical) nystagmus and evidence of vertical skew, a central vestibular syndrome.is the most probable cause. The differential diagnosis includes cerebral infarction or hemorrhage in the brainstem, cerebellum, or demyelination. Neuroimaging with brain magnetic resonance imaging with contrast can be diagnostic.        

Episodic vertigo, as opposed to persistent vertigo as seen in this patient, can be caused by benign paroxysmal positional vertigo or Ménière’s disease. A positive Dix-Hallpike test indicates BPPV.   

Option Analysis

✅ Finger rub test :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging can determine the cause of an acute central vestibular syndrome; however, this patient presents with findings consistent with peripheral vestibular syndrome, decreased hearing of the right side with finger rub test would indicate labyrinthitis (and not vestibular neuritis) as the cause.  
❌ Computerized tomography of the head:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging can help determine the cause of an acute central vestibular syndrome; however, this patient presents with findings consistent with a peripheral vestibular syndrome. The finding of decreased hearing in the right ear with finger rub test would indicate that labyrinthitis is the cause. 
❌ Sequencing of the NF2 gene:
Incorrect: Neurofibromatosis type 2 can lead to a vestibular schwannoma or acoustic neuroma. It is diagnosed with genetic testing of the NF2 gene. Neurofibromatosis type 2 can be a rare cause of persistent vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and other neurological symptoms. Vestibular neuritis and labyrinthitis are much more common causes of peripheral vestibulopathy.  
❌ Dix-Hallpike test:
Incorrect: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo may be confirmed with an abnormal Dix-Hallpike test however BPPV presents with episodic rather than persistent vertigo as seen in this patient. Decreased hearing of the right ear with a finger rub test in this patient would indicate labyrinthitis as the cause.

questions.text: A 56-year-old-woman presents to the cardiology clinic for follow-up of hypertension. Lately, her blood pressure has been within goal range, but she reports feeling excessively sleepy during the day despite sleeping 7-8 hours nightly. Her partner notes that she snores loudly throughout the night. She has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and takes lisinopril and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Body mass index (BMI) is 30 kg/m2. On exam, she is alert. She has a deviated nasal septum, mild retrognathia, and enlarged tonsillar tissue. Cardiac examination reveals normal heart sounds with a regular rate and rhythm. Which of the following diagnostic tests will most likely confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 56-year-old woman presents with snoring, poor sleep quality, and excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS), along with risk factors for IOSA including hypertension, enlarged tonsillar tissue, and obesity. The most likely diagnosis is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Overnight polysomnography (PSG) showing apneas can be used to diagnose OSA.        

An overnight PSG records brain waves, oxygenation, heart rate, respiratory rate, and eye and limb movements in sleep. An apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) measures how often a patient’s breathing stops or slows in sleep. An AHI of at least 5 times per hour is diagnostic for sleep apnea.        

Sleep apnea may occur as the result of an anatomical obstruction to airflow. Risk factors for OSA include obesity, alcohol use or use of other sedatives, smoking, and atrial fibrillation. Anatomic factors, like an increased neck circumference or enlarged structures in the oropharynx may also contribute. Alternatively, central sleep apnea occurs due to lack of respiratory drive, either due to structural brain lesions or use of sedating medications.        

Treatment of both types of sleep apnea includes positive pressure support of the airway, often through continuous or bilevel positive airway pressure (i.e., CPAP or BiPAP).   

Option Analysis

✅ Overnight polysomnography:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Serum iron level:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency can contribute to restless leg symptoms, but this patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) and snoring is concerning for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which can be diagnosed with an overnight polysomnogram. 
❌ Serum ethanol level:
Incorrect: Excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) and nocturnal snoring could be the result of alcohol use, but this patient’s symptoms, signs, and physical exam findings of retrognathia, enlarged tonsillar tissue, and obesity are concerning for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OSA can be diagnosed with an overnight polysomnogram. 
❌ Laryngoscopy:
Incorrect: Craniofacial and upper airway disorders that may be seen with laryngoscopy may increase the risk of OSA, but overnight polysomnography is needed to diagnose OSA.  
❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect: Though structural brain abnormalities may result in either central or obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), the most appropriate diagnostic test for this patient with signs and symptoms of OSA, and retrognathia, enlarged tonsillar tissue and obesity is an overnight polysomnogram to investigate for apnea.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute-onset blurry vision in the left eye associated with severe left eye pain. She has not experienced ocular trauma. That morning, she noticed pain in the left eye along with seeing halos around lights. She feels nauseous and has a severe headache. She has a past medical history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, allergic rhinitis, and hypertension. She takes metformin and lisinopril, and intranasal fluticasone as needed. She wears contact lenses and cleans them nightly. Family history is significant for multiple sclerosis in her mother. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg. Visual acuity is 20/20 OD and 20/50 OS. The left eye pain worsens when the lights are dimmed. There is conjunctival injection in the left eye, and the left pupil is fixed and dilated. There is no discharge. Fundoscopy reveals left optic disc edema. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for the underlying cause of this patient’s vision loss?
questions.solution:
This 72-year-old patient presents with severe unilateral acute-onset painful vision loss, and eye redness. She reports seeing halos around lights and has associated nausea and headache. On physical examination she has a fixed and dilated pupil in the affected eye, conjunctival injection, and optic disc edema. These findings are consistent with acute angle closure glaucoma, which is caused by a rapid increase in intraocular pressure due to outflow obstruction of aqueous humor. Risk factors for the development of acute angle closure glaucoma include advanced age, female biological sex, and use of certain medications.        

Examination of patients presenting with acute vision loss will reveal decreased visual acuity and/or impaired visual fields, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and abnormal fundoscopy. Painful ophthalmological causes of acute vision loss associated with conjunctival injection include infectious keratitis and acute angle closure glaucoma. If the patient has a headache with nausea or vomiting and symptoms that worsen upon entering a dark room and halos around lights, then acute angle closure glaucoma is the likely diagnosis. Tonometry and gonioscopy will demonstrate increased intraocular pressure confirming the diagnosis. Acute angle closure glaucoma is an emergent condition requiring immediate intervention to prevent permanent vision loss.    

Option Analysis

✅ Age :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Contact lens use:
Incorrect: Infectious keratitis can be caused by unhygienic use of contacts; however, patients typically present with corneal opacification and mucopurulent discharge. 
❌ Family history of multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Patients with optic neuritis present with acute-onset vision loss, but unlike with acute angle closure glaucoma, there would be no conjunctival injection or red eye. 
❌ Allergic rhinitis:
Incorrect: Allergic conjunctivitis can cause irritated red eyes bilaterally and may be associated with rhinitis and other allergic symptoms. However, unilateral severe pain would not be seen.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled DM can lead to diabetic retinopathy; however, patients are typically asymptomatic until late stages where they can have decreased visual acuity without pain or conjunctival injection.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is hospitalized for new-onset weakness. Two days ago, she said that both of her feet began tingling and her legs began feeling weak. These symptoms rapidly worsened yesterday resulting in a fall and prompting an evaluation in the emergency department. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medications. She received routine immunizations three weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, there is symmetric bilateral lower extremity weakness and sensory loss with absent deep tendon reflexes. A bedside forced vital capacity is normal. A diagnostic lumbar puncture shows an elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein level and normal white blood cell count. Electrodiagnostic studies show conduction delay and a denervation pattern. In addition to supportive care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with rapidly progressive ascending weakness following exposure to a known trigger with confirmatory diagnostic testing for Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). Treatment is with immunomodulatory therapy, either intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasma exchange.        

In addition to immunomodulatory therapy, patients with GBS should have supportive care. This includes respiratory support with frequent reassessment of respiratory function with bedside pulmonary function tests. Patients should initially be monitored for worsening symptoms with serial neurologic examinations performed daily. Some patients may have labile blood pressure, arrhythmias, and other signs of cardiovascular compromise from dysautonomia, which requires monitoring and possibly other management strategies. Due to reduced mobility, preventative measures should include deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis and pressure ulcer prevention measures. Consultation with physical and occupational therapy helps with early rehabilitation to prevent deconditioning. Finally, some patients may require pain management.        

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids have not been shown to reduce disease severity or duration in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome and may lead to adverse effects. 
❌ Botulism antitoxin:
Incorrect: Foodborne botulism as a result of ingestion of C. botulinum spores may cause descending weakness, first affecting the neck and arms. This patient’s weakness is in an ascending pattern consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome, which should be treated with IVIG. 
❌ Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome represents an immune-mediated – rather than primary infectious – process that often occurs in response to a viral or other antigenic trigger. Treatment is with immunomodulatory therapy rather than with antimicrobial therapy. 
❌ Intravenous anti-hypertensives:
Incorrect: While patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome may display evidence of cardiovascular instability secondary to dysautonomia, the blood pressure is often labile, and use of antihypertensives may cause hypotension. Definitive treatment is with immunomodulatory therapy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic for evaluation of weakness. For the past several years, he has noticed gradually progressive, persistent weakness of both hands, leading to difficulty opening jars, dressing, and writing. These symptoms do not change throughout the day. His past medical history includes hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. There is no family history of similar symptoms. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/85 mmHg. On physical exam, he is alert and has normal facial muscle strength. No abnormal skin lesions are present. Bilateral muscle weakness is noted, particularly in finger flexion, knee extension, and dorsiflexion of the feet. Atrophy of the quadriceps is also observed. Sensation is intact throughout. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests can help confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 60-year-old patient presents with symmetric, slowly progressive, predominantly distal, bilateral weakness with a normal sensory exam, which is concerning for a muscle disease—specifically inclusion body myositis. A muscle biopsy can confirm the diagnosis by revealing rimmed vacuoles in myofibers.        

The differential diagnosis of a patient suspected of having a muscle disease can be narrowed based on family history, tempo of symptoms, and pattern of muscle weakness (e.g. proximal versus distal muscle weakness). In cases where the diagnosis is unclear or further confirmation is needed, a muscle biopsy and/or genetic testing may be warranted.   





Option Analysis

✅ Muscle biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sequencing of the CACNA1S or SCN4A genes:
Incorrect: Both hypo- and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis are in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient’s persistent, predominantly distal weakness suggests inclusion body myositis, which can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy. 
❌ Deletion/duplication analysis of the DMD gene:
Incorrect: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies are in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient’s age and persistent, predominantly distal weakness suggest inclusion body myositis, which can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy. 
❌ Repeat expansion analysis of the DMPK gene:
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy is in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient has no evidence of the commonly associated temporal and masseter muscle wasting, and he has persistent, predominantly distal weakness, which suggests inclusion body myositis—a diagnosis that can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy. 
❌ Serum potassium level:
Incorrect: Both hypo- and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis are in the differential for a patient presenting with weakness. However, this patient’s persistent, predominantly distal weakness suggests inclusion body myositis, which can be confirmed with a muscle biopsy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider’s office for evaluation of recurrent episodes of unilateral, pulsating headaches lasting hours to two days in duration and associated with photophobia. The headaches have been occurring over the past year. Past medical history is noncontributory. Current medication includes an oral contraceptive. She occasionally uses over-the-counter analgesics such as acetaminophen for headaches. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. Examination reveals normal strength, reflexes, sensation, and coordination, with a normal fundoscopic examination. Mental status, cranial nerve, and neck exams are within normal limits. Which of the following findings would indicate the need for further evaluation for an underlying cause of the headaches?

choices.text: Worsening intensity of the headaches with Valsalva maneuvers

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of symptoms of unilateral pulsatile headaches lasting hours to days, associated with nausea and photophobia, and a normal neurologic exam. These findings are consistent with migraine headaches without aura. Migraines are an example of a primary headache disorder. Primary headache disorders can be diagnosed once secondary causes of headaches are ruled out. Indications of a potential secondary cause of a headache include recent medication changes, head trauma, and fever. Findings of change in the headache quality with lying flat and sitting up or standing are associated with changes in intracranial pressure. Headaches that worsen with Valsalva maneuvers (i.e., coughing, straining) are also concerning for underlying increased intracranial pressure. These findings should prompt further workup to rule out secondary causes of headaches.

Primary headaches (the most common of which are migraines, tension-type headaches, and cluster headaches) are not affected by positional changes (i.e. the quality of the headache does not change whether the person is lying down versus sitting or standing up). Sneezing, coughing, or straining should not intensify the pain. The fundoscopic exam should reveal sharp optic discs bilaterally. Neurological symptoms including light or sound sensitivity, nausea, vomiting, or dysautonomia may be present with certain primary headaches. Migraines with auras may have preceding focal neurological deficits including changes in vision, speech, sensation, motor strength, equilibrium, or even level of consciousness.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Worsening intensity of the headaches with Valsalva maneuvers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Associated vomiting:
Incorrect: Vomiting is a common symptom of migraine headaches, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. Before a diagnosis of a primary headache disorder such as migraines is made, signs and symptoms associated with secondary headaches should be ruled out. Increased intracranial pressure can cause headaches that increase in intensity with Valsalva maneuvers; therefore, this finding would indicate the need for further evaluation.
❌ Associated phonophobia:
Incorrect: Phonophobia, or sound sensitivity, is a common symptom associated with migraine headaches, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, patients with headaches should be evaluated for signs and symptoms consistent with secondary headaches. If any are present, they should be further evaluated before a diagnosis of primary headaches can be made.
❌ Family history of migraine headaches:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches have a high rate of heritability, so this finding would be consistent with migraines, the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, patients with headaches should be evaluated for signs and symptoms consistent with secondary headaches, and if any are present, they should be further evaluated before a diagnosis of primary headache can be made.
❌ Up-to-date immunization status:
Incorrect: Being fully vaccinated and up-to-date on immunizations would decrease the chance of an underlying vaccine-preventable infectious process as the cause of a headache and would not require further evaluation before a diagnosis of migraines could be made in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of an intensely painful unilateral headache behind the left eye. He has had recurrent, brief episodes of similar severe, stabbing head pain behind the left eye over the past year. Typically, the episodes last 30 minutes and recur daily for several weeks, and then they resolve spontaneously. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medication aside from occasional over-the-counter analgesics, which have not been helpful for the pain. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears agitated and is in distress secondary to pain. The left eyelid is swollen, with conjunctival injection and excessive tearing. Which of the following additional findings would be expected given the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of a cluster headache, which is a primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent, brief episodes of severe, unilateral, periorbital pain associated with agitation and dysautonomia. Signs of dysautonomia include miosis of the ipsilateral eye, ipsilateral nasal congestion or rhinorrhea, and ipsilateral lacrimation, sweating, and restlessness.

Primary headache disorders are more likely to occur in patients <50 years of age who have no history of trauma, no systemic symptoms, and no history of malignancy or immunodeficiency. Primary headaches are not affected by positional changes and are not exacerbated by Valsalva maneuvers or jaw movement. Patients with primary headaches have normal neurological examinations between episodes.

Cluster headache is a type of trigeminal autonomic cephalgia, which is a primary headache characterized by the presence of symptoms of dysautonomia, such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, nasal congestion or rhinorrhea, eyelid edema, facial sweating, miosis, or ptosis.

The clinical symptoms and examination findings associated with the distinct types of primary headaches are detailed in the table above. Differentiating between the diverse types of primary headaches can often be done based on history and physical examination alone, without further diagnostic testing.
   



Option Analysis

✅ Miosis of the left eye:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Photophobia:
Incorrect: Photophobia is a common symptom associated with migraines and some secondary causes of headaches. This patient presents with symptoms and signs of cluster headaches, which are not associated with photophobia and are instead associated with signs of dysautonomia, such as ipsilateral miosis.
❌ Focal limb weakness:
Incorrect: Focal limb weakness may occur with a hemiplegic migraine or with certain secondary causes of headaches. This patient presents with symptoms and signs of cluster headaches, which are not associated with focal limb weakness and are instead associated with signs of dysautonomia such as ipsilateral miosis.
❌ Nausea:
Incorrect: Nausea is a common symptom of migraines and some secondary causes of headaches. However, this patient presents with symptoms and signs consistent with a cluster headache, which is characterized by dysautonomia such as ipsilateral miosis.
❌ Paresthesias:
Incorrect: Paresthesias may occur with migraine with aura or with some secondary causes of headaches. However, this patient presents with symptoms and signs consistent with a cluster headache, which is characterized by dysautonomia such as ipsilateral miosis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening weakness for the past two months. She has noted difficulty brushing her hair, rising from a chair, and has occasionally choked while eating dinner. Additionally, her eyelids have appeared droopy while applying her makeup for the past week. This morning, she developed double vision and slurred speech. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no regular medication. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. On exam, she appears alert with hypophonic speech. She has bilateral ptosis, neck flexor weakness, and weakness of the bilateral shoulder abductors and hip flexors. Sensation is intact. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of myasthenia gravis, characterized by painless and fluctuating weakness, ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, and dysphagia. Neuromuscular junction dysfunction can affect the muscles of respiration; therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to assess respiratory muscle strength through bedside pulmonary function tests (PFTs), such as measurement of negative inspiratory force. These patients should also have intravenous (IV) access established and undergo continuous vital sign monitoring.

Neuromuscular junction disorders often present with painless muscle weakness, ocular symptoms (e.g. double vision), or bulbar symptoms affecting speech or swallowing. Physical examination may reveal cranial nerve impairment (e.g., ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and facial muscle weakness), as well as neck and proximal limb weakness, while sensation remains intact.

The first step in evaluating a patient suspected of having a neuromuscular junction disorder is to look for signs of diaphragmatic weakness. If unrecognized, this may lead to rapid respiratory failure. Bedside pulmonary function tests may reveal reduced vital capacity, maximal inspiratory pressure (negative inspiratory force), and maximal expiratory pressure. Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation or intubation may be necessary to stabilize the airway and breathing if these findings are present.

Option Analysis

✅ Negative inspiratory force:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid stimulating hormone level:
Incorrect: Weakness can be a sign of thyroid dysfunction; however, this patient presents with symptoms of neuromuscular junction dysfunction, which can affect diaphragmatic strength and respiration. Due to the risk of rapid respiratory decline, bedside pulmonary function testing should be the priority.
❌ Creatine kinase level:
Incorrect: Although a creatine kinase level may be elevated in patients with weakness, the priority is to perform bedside pulmonary function testing first as respiratory muscle involvement can rapidly lead to respiratory failure.
❌ Electromyogram and nerve conduction study:
Incorrect: Electrophysiology tests can prove helpful in the evaluation of a patient presenting with weakness, but acute management for patients with a neuromuscular junction disorder is to assess the strength of the muscles of respiration through bedside pulmonary function tests.
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: Chest radiography is helpful in the evaluation of a patient with respiratory distress, but only after immediate stabilization of the airway and breathing. This patient is at risk for respiratory failure secondary to neuromuscular junction dysfunction, for which bedside pulmonary function tests are indicated.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services for evaluation of lethargy. Her roommate found her slumped in her desk chair, poorly responsive, and ill-appearing. Past medical history is notable for major depressive disorder for which she inconsistently takes citalopram. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/85 mmHg. On exam, she appears alert and endorses nausea and double vision. She has bilateral ptosis, dysarthria, diaphoresis, watery eyes, and drooling. She has difficulty getting out of bed after an episode of emesis and fecal incontinence. Her complete blood count (CBC) with differential, comprehensive metabolic profile (CMP), urine toxicology screen, and serum hCG are unremarkable. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests can help confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Positive response to administration of atropine
Serum anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) and anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies
Improvement of symptoms with administration of edrophonium

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of organophosphate toxicity as evidenced by painless, nonfluctuating weakness alongside a cholinergic toxidrome (diaphoresis, salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, and emesis). Organophosphates are widely used in certain pesticides, and ingestion or exposure can be inadvertent or may occur during a suicide attempt. Such exposure to these compounds leads to inhibition of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). Administration of atropine, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, can improve cholinergic symptoms and support the diagnosis.

In evaluating a possible neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder, the presence or absence of symptom fluctuation is key. Additional diagnostic tools that can help differentiate between various etiologies include an ice pack test, nerve conduction studies, electromyography (EMG), and antibody assays (e.g., anti–AChR, anti–MuSK, anti-VGCC) are helpful in diagnosing disorders like myasthenia gravis and Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome – both of which characteristically fluctuate and often improve with tests that enhance NMJ transmission (e.g. edrophonium test).

In contrast, organophosphate poisoning and botulism tend to present with nonfluctuating weakness, although their associated gastrointestinal symptoms help distinguish them. Botulism typically presents with constipation and a positive C. botulinum culture, whereas organophosphate toxicity causes vomiting and diarrhea, and responds to atropine or pralidoxime.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Positive response to administration of atropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) and anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholinergic symptoms are concerning for organophosphate toxicity, which causes inhibition of acetylcholinesterase. These symptoms typically improve with the administration of atropine. Anti-AChR and anti-MuSK antibodies are seen with myasthenia gravis, a fluctuating neuromuscular junction disorder.
❌ Serum anti-voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) antibodies:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholinergic symptoms are concerning for organophosphate toxicity. These symptoms should improve with the administration of atropine. Anti-VGCC antibodies are seen with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a fluctuating neuromuscular junction disorder.
❌ Improvement of symptoms with administration of edrophonium:
Incorrect: A positive edrophonium test suggests either myasthenia gravis or Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome and can actually worsen the symptoms of acetylcholinesterase inhibition due to organophosphate toxicity.
❌ Positive Clostridium botulinum stool culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholinergic symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea are concerning for organophosphate toxicity, which should improve with administration of atropine. In contrast, botulism typically presents with constipation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. For the past year, the patient has felt increasingly unsteady, and for the past six months has had several near-falls. The patient feels even more unsteady in the dark or when his eyes are closed. Past medical history includes hypertension, which is well-controlled with lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient’s gait is wide-based with forceful stepping. Dimming the lights while the patient walks causes more unsteadiness. Serum hemoglobin A1c and vitamin B12 levels are normal. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Serologic and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) syphilis testing
Frataxin gene mutation with expanded GAA repeats
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with unsteadiness, frequent falls, and a stomping gait pattern characterized by forceful, wide-based steps that worsens in low light. In the absence of diabetes mellitus or vitamin B12 deficiency, tabes dorsalis is the most likely diagnosis. On magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), longitudinal T2 hyperintensities in the posterior spinal cord may be seen, but these findings are neither sensitive nor specific. The most definitive evidence comes from positive syphilis serology and a reactive VDRL in the cerebrospinal fluid.

Patients may experience gait dysfunction because of motor weakness, sensory loss, poor coordination, or movement disorders. These issues can result in various gait patterns, including spastic, stomping, steppage, ataxic, and Parkinsonian gait. Assessing the pattern of gait dysfunction helps narrow the differential diagnosis and direct further diagnostic testing, such as imaging studies, genetic testing, laboratory tests, and electromyography and nerve conduction studies. The table above provides more detailed guidance on next steps based on suspected etiology.

Option Analysis

✅ Serologic and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) syphilis testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ PMP22 gene duplication:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a stomping gait pattern (i.e., wide-based, unsteady, forceful steps) rather than the steppage gait pattern (i.e., excessive hip flexion, high steps, foot drop) associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. Given the normal hemoglobin A1c and vitamin B12 levels, tabes dorsalis should be considered; this can be confirmed through serologic and CSF testing for syphilis.
❌ Frataxin gene mutation with expanded GAA repeats:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a stomping gait pattern (i.e., wide-based, unsteady, forceful steps) rather than the ataxic gait pattern (i.e., wide-based, veering to the side, irregular rhythm, and stride length) associated with Friedreich ataxia. Given the normal hemoglobin A1c and vitamin B12 levels, tabes dorsalis should be considered; this can be confirmed through serologic and CSF testing for syphilis.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a stomping gait pattern, which can be associated with tabes dorsalis, vitamin B12 deficiency, or diabetic neuropathy. Given the normal hemoglobin A1c and vitamin B12 levels, tabes dorsalis should be considered; this can be confirmed through serologic and CSF syphilis testing. Imaging of the spine can sometimes show longitudinal hyperintensities in the dorsal columns, but this finding is neither sensitive nor specific for tabes dorsalis.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a stomping gait pattern, which can be associated with tabes dorsalis, vitamin B12 deficiency, or diabetic neuropathy. Brain imaging is not diagnostic for these causes. Because this patient’s hemoglobin A1c and vitamin B12 levels were normal, serologic and CSF testing for syphilis are indicated to evaluate for tabes dorsalis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of numbness and tingling in the right hand, which has been present for the past three weeks. The patient has difficulty buttoning shirts and experiences increased pain as a receptionist. Past medical history is non-contributory, and the patient takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mmHg. The patient endorses numbness over the palm, thumb, and first two fingers. There is weakness with thumb abduction. Phalen and Tinel signs are positive. Which of the following historical findings may contribute to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of compressive median neuropathy, or carpal tunnel syndrome, as evidenced by numbness, tingling, pain, and weakness of the first three fingers, which worsen with repetitive motions. Pregnant individuals are at increased risk of developing this condition due to hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening.  

Compressive neuropathies occur due to mechanical entrapment of peripheral nerves, resulting in paresthesias, pain, or weakness. Without treatment, this can result in demyelination and axonal injury. Specific nerve impingement syndromes can impair the ability to perform everyday tasks, such as difficulty using the hands or experiencing foot drop or toe dragging while walking.

Certain medical conditions predispose patients to compressive neuropathies, including diabetes, hypothyroidism, obesity, pregnancy, trauma, and rheumatoid arthritis. Additionally, activities such as cycling, playing a musical instrument, maintaining certain positions for prolonged periods, or wearing tight clothing can precipitate compression.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pregnancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Smoking:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy due to hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Smoking is not a known risk factor for this condition.
❌ Caffeine use:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy because of hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Caffeine use is not a known risk factor for this condition.
❌ Anxiety:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy because of hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Anxiety is not a known risk factor for this condition.
❌ Injury to the elbow:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compressive median neuropathy, which can occur with pregnancy because of hormonal changes, fluid retention, and ligament softening. Compression at the elbow is more likely to cause ulnar neuropathy, which would affect the 4th and 5th fingers.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of weakness. Two days ago, the patient’s legs felt heavy, which was attributed to exercise. This morning, the weakness worsened, and the patient started tripping on the stairs. A review of systems reveals recent gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea and abdominal cramping. The patient feels unable to catch his breath. There is no significant past medical history, and no daily medication is taken. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. There is symmetric bilateral weakness with ankle dorsiflexion and knee flexion and extension, as well as a loss of vibration sense. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following laboratory study results is most likely to be associated with this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) white blood cell count
Elevated serum very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) level

questions.solution:
This patient presents with rapidly progressive ascending weakness and areflexia after a recent gastrointestinal illness, suggesting Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), an acquired polyneuropathy. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing typically shows albuminocytologic dissociation, with an elevated protein level and normal white blood cell count.

Polyneuropathies are associated with demyelination or axonal injury of multiple peripheral nerves. Etiologies can be hereditary or acquired, and the differential diagnosis can often be narrowed by the family history or the timing of symptom progression. Acquired polyneuropathies with acute presentations include GBS and critical illness polyneuropathy, while those with more chronic, progressive presentations include vitamin B12 deficiency, as well as diabetic and alcoholic neuropathies.

Genetic testing is available to distinguish between Friedrich ataxia, which is associated with trinucleotide repeat expansions in the frataxin gene, adrenomyeloneuropathy, which is associated with mutations in the ABCD1 gene, and Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1a, which is associated with duplication of the PMP22 gene. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis (e.g. albuminocytologic dissociation in GBS) or serum laboratory analyses (e.g. vitamin B12 level) can be helpful in distinguishing between the various acquired causes of polyneuropathy.

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) white blood cell count:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with albuminocytologic disassociation. In this condition, the CSF protein level is elevated, while the white blood cell count remains normal.
❌ Decreased serum vitamin B12 level:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with an elevated CSF protein level. Polyneuropathy due to vitamin B12 deficiency is typically slowly progressive and presents with sensory symptoms such as numbness or tingling.
❌ Elevated serum hemoglobin A1c level:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with an elevated CSF protein level. Diabetic polyneuropathy is a slowly progressive condition associated with long-standing poor glucose control.
❌ Elevated serum very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) level:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with an elevated CSF protein level. Adrenomyeloneuropathy, which is associated with elevated VLCFA levels, typically presents as a slowly progressive polyneuropathy.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right arm weakness. The symptoms began suddenly during dinner with friends, accompanied by an intense headache. The patient leaned to the right in the chair, dropped a cup, and became aphasic. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia managed with metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 56/min, respirations are 8-10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 188/90 mmHg. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 8. Eyes are open, and the patient withdraws the left extremities to pain but has no verbal response. Flaccid paralysis is present in the right upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast
Flatten the head of the bed

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of a secondary headache and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), including Cushing triad (bradycardia, irregular respirations, and hypertension). Acute management includes stabilization of the airway and breathing with intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Headache and facial pain are common presentations with a broad differential, ranging from benign to life-threatening causes. Primary headaches, which are not due to underlying pathology, include tension-type headache, cluster headache, and migraine. In contrast, secondary headaches result from an underlying condition, such as giant cell arteritis, infectious meningitis, or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

In any unstable adult with headache or facial pain, the first step is to assess and stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Intravenous access should be established, and vital signs continuously monitored. In patients unable to protect their airway or experiencing respiratory failure, intubation and mechanical ventilation may be warranted. In the presence of increased ICP, immediate interventions include elevating the head of the bed, initiating hyperventilation, providing sedation, and administering hyperosmolar therapy.

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast:
Incorrect: Although a non-contrast CT is essential for evaluating acute neurologic changes, airway protection must take priority in a patient with a GCS of 8 and irregular respirations. Imaging should follow intubation.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without contrast:
Incorrect: MRI is not appropriate as an initial imaging study in an unstable patient. It requires more time and is less readily available than CT. Immediate airway stabilization should precede all imaging.
❌ Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA):
Incorrect: Thrombolytics are contraindicated until hemorrhage is excluded by imaging. Additionally, this patient requires airway protection prior to any further intervention.
❌ Flatten the head of the bed:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs of increased intracranial pressure, which can be managed with elevation of the head of the bed (rather than lowering it) in addition to hyperventilation, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a supervisor for evaluation of injuries sustained during a fall. The two were working at a construction site when the patient fell backwards off a ladder, striking the back of his head on the cement driveway. The patient was able to stand at the scene and initially expressed head pain, but he has since become increasingly confused and drowsy. Medical history includes hypertension and tobacco use. Medications include lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is currently 11 but was 14 at the scene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 31-year-old individual presents after blunt head trauma with progressive confusion and drowsiness, which are hallmark features of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The key historical feature is the transiently preserved neurologic state followed by rapid deterioration, which suggests a lucid interval and is most characteristic of an epidural hematoma.

Symptoms such as headache, nausea, altered mental status, and a declining Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score can signal rising ICP. Physical exam features may include the Cushing triad (bradycardia, hypertension, irregular respirations), unilateral or bilateral pupil dilation, papilledema, and cranial nerve palsies.

While other intracranial pathologies such as subdural hematoma, ischemic stroke, or infection may also cause increased ICP, the tempo of symptom progression and trauma history are essential diagnostic clues. Subdural hematomas may progress more slowly. Ischemic strokes often lack an initial trauma trigger. Infectious causes usually involve fever or systemic signs. Computed tomography (CT) imaging is critical to confirm the diagnosis and identify features such as a biconvex (lentiform) hyperdensity confined by suture lines, which is classic for an epidural hematoma. Additional signs of elevated ICP may include effacement of sulci, midline shift, or herniation.

Option Analysis

✅ Epidural hematoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subdural hematoma:
Incorrect: A subdural hematoma may occur after trauma and can present acutely, particularly with high-impact injury. However, it typically progresses more gradually than an epidural hematoma, which is often arterial in origin and associated with rapid deterioration.
❌ Brain abscess:
Incorrect: While a brain abscess can cause headache, confusion, and signs of increased intracranial pressure, it usually presents in the context of infection or immunosuppression. This patient's acute presentation following trauma is more consistent with intracranial hemorrhage.
❌ Ischemic stroke:
Incorrect: Ischemic stroke is less likely given the traumatic mechanism and the stepwise decline in consciousness in this case. While large vessel occlusion can cause rapid symptoms, this presentation is more suggestive of traumatic hemorrhage.
❌ Encephalitis:
Incorrect: Encephalitis can present with headache, confusion, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. However, the acute onset following head trauma and absence of fever make encephalitis unlikely in this case.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services for evaluation of vomiting and lethargy. A roommate found the patient unresponsive in bed, surrounded by emesis, with a note and an empty bottle of acetaminophen. Past medical history includes depression managed with sertraline. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 168/85 mmHg. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is 8. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. Which of the following is the most likely finding on computed tomography (CT) imaging of the head?

choices.text: Hypodensity within the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory

questions.solution:
This 21-year-old patient presents with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), including lethargy and papilledema following a toxic ingestion. Acute liver failure from acetaminophen toxicity can cause hyperammonemia, which leads to cerebral edema. This may appear on neuroimaging as a loss of gray-white matter differentiation.

After initial stabilization and supportive care, a computed tomography (CT) of the head can help identify whether the increase in ICP is secondary to expansion of the cerebrospinal fluid, blood, or brain compartments. Imaging may demonstrate ventriculomegaly, hemorrhage or vascular expansion such as an aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, mass effect, ischemia, or cerebral edema. Blurring of the margins between the gray and white matter regions within the brain parenchyma, along with effacement of sulci and ventricles, suggests cerebral edema.  

Once the underlying cause of increased ICP is identified, definitive treatment can proceed. In cases of cerebral edema, management focuses on preventing further injury by addressing the underlying cause. For acetaminophen overdose, appropriate interventions include gastrointestinal decontamination, early administration of N-acetylcysteine, hyperosmolar therapy, and ICP monitoring.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of gray-white differentiation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventriculomegaly:
Incorrect: Although hydrocephalus and ventriculomegaly can cause increased intracranial pressure, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with diffuse cerebral edema from metabolic derangement, which is characterized by loss of gray-white matter differentiation.
❌ Hyperdensity within the basal cisterns:
Incorrect: Hyperdensity in the basal cisterns is typical of subarachnoid hemorrhage, which presents with sudden-onset headache and altered mental status. This patient’s symptoms are more likely due to diffuse cerebral edema from metabolic derangement related to an overdose, which features loss of gray-white differentiation.
❌ Hypodensity within the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory:
Incorrect: While an MCA ischemic stroke can cause increased intracranial pressure, this patient’s symptoms are more likely due to diffuse cerebral edema from a metabolic derangement related to overdose, which is characterized by loss of gray-white matter differentiation.
❌ Crescent-shaped hyperdensity crossing suture lines:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of a subdural hematoma, usually is associated with trauma or anticoagulation. There is no history of head trauma in this case, and the clinical presentation is more consistent with a toxic-metabolic process related to an overdose. Loss of gray-white matter differentiation would be expected.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion and forgetfulness for the past three weeks. According to a family member, the patient has also been more emotional than usual. Review of systems is negative for recent constitutional symptoms. Past medical history includes hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease, for which the patient takes lisinopril and omeprazole, respectively. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears tearful with intermittent, brief twitching of the left side of the face and arm. A urine drug screen and serum ethanol level are negative. A complete blood count (CBC) with differential is normal. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-LGI1 antibodies
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-NMDA receptor antibodies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of autoimmune encephalitis, including subacute memory loss, emotional lability, and involuntary facial and arm movements consistent with faciobrachial dystonic seizures. The absence of fever or other signs of infection supports a non-infectious etiology. The most likely diagnosis is anti-leucine-rich-glioma-inactivated 1 (LGI1) encephalitis, which can be confirmed by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-LGI1 antibodies.       

Encephalitis can occur from both infectious and autoimmune etiologies. A focused history and physical examination can help narrow the differential diagnosis and guide further evaluation. When infection is suspected, such as in the presence of fever or systemic symptoms, CSF studies can be used to identify specific pathogens through PCR or antibody testing.         

In cases without evidence of infection, autoimmune etiologies should be considered. Rapid-onset symptoms over days may suggest acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), while a subacute progression over weeks is more typical of anti-NMDA receptor or anti-LGI1 encephalitis. Both can present with abnormal movements, memory deficits, and behavioral changes. Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is more common in younger individuals, particularly women, whereas anti-LGI1 encephalitis more often affects adults over the age of 50. Faciobrachial dystonic seizures, memory impairment, and emotional lability are particularly characteristic of anti-LGI1 encephalitis. The presence of specific autoantibodies confirms the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-LGI1 antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for anti-NMDA receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis more commonly affects younger individuals and can present with a viral-like prodrome, psychiatric symptoms, sleep disturbances, language dysfunction, and abnormal movements. However, the facial and arm twitching observed in this patient is consistent with faciobrachial dystonic seizures. Combined with the patient’s age and emotional lability, anti-LGI1 encephalitis is more likely.
❌ Serum anti-MOG antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-MOG antibodies are typically seen in younger individuals with demyelinating syndromes such as acute disseminated encephalomyelitis. This patient's age, emotional lability, subacute presentation, and characteristic faciobrachial dystonic seizures suggest anti-LGI1 encephalitis. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for HSV-1/2 PCR:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus encephalitis often presents with fever, prodromal symptoms, and altered mental status. Although afebrile cases can occur, the presence of faciobrachial dystonic seizures and the subacute progression in this case are more consistent with anti-LGI1 encephalitis. 
❌ Serum anti-HIV-1/2 RNA PCR assay:
Incorrect: Individuals with HIV are at increased risk for infectious causes of encephalitis. However, this patient has no signs of infection, and the subacute presentation is more consistent with a paraneoplastic or autoimmune process.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a one-year history of gradually worsening forgetfulness. The patient has forgotten important appointments and needs lists to complete routine errands. Recently, the patient lost her car in a parking garage and was irritated after struggling to prepare a familiar recipe. Past medical history is notable for gastroesophageal reflux treated with omeprazole. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears alert, oriented, and interactive. Neurological examination reveals no focal deficits. The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score is 23/30, and depression screening suggests minimal to no symptoms. Which of the following historical findings is most important to elicit before proceeding with further diagnostic testing?

choices.text: Anxiety, heat intolerance, weight loss, and palpitations

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of Alzheimer disease, including slowly progressive memory loss, difficulty performing everyday tasks, and at least mild cognitive impairment in the absence of depression. Some metabolic conditions, including vitamin B12 deficiency, can mimic these symptoms. The initial evaluation should include an investigation for this potentially reversible cause, such as insufficient dietary intake or malabsorption.         

Patients with Alzheimer disease typically present with slowly progressive cognitive decline. Symptoms include episodic memory loss, impaired visuospatial function, and difficulty planning or executing complex tasks.        

The first step in assessing a patient with suspected Alzheimer disease is to review medications and substances and to screen for underlying medical conditions that could cause cognitive impairment. Vitamin B12 deficiency, hypothyroidism, depression, and other structural brain lesions must be ruled out before confirming a diagnosis of Alzheimer disease.    

Option Analysis

✅ Dietary habits:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Smoking history  :
Incorrect: Although smoking can increase the risk of developing Alzheimer disease, reversible causes of dementia, such as diet-related conditions, should be considered first.    
❌ Anxiety, heat intolerance, weight loss, and palpitations:
Incorrect: These symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism. Hypothyroidism, rather than hyperthyroidism, is a potentially reversible cause of cognitive decline. Vitamin B12 deficiency, which is common among those following a vegan diet, is another reversible cause. 
❌ Abnormal movements:
Incorrect: Some causes of gradual cognitive decline feature abnormal movements, such as Huntington disease or dementia with Lewy bodies. Reversible medical causes should be ruled out first, including vitamin B12 deficiency, which is more likely in individuals following a vegan diet. 
❌ Partner with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV):
Incorrect: Although HIV infection can induce gradual cognitive decline, more common and potentially reversible medical causes, such as diet-related vitamin B12 deficiency, should be ruled out first.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker for altered mental status. Earlier that afternoon during a meeting, the patient suddenly appeared confused, staring at his right hand. When asked to look at the slide on the left side of the screen, the patient looked to the right instead, appearing confused about which side was left. The patient was unable to continue taking notes and asked for “You know, the thing you use to write with.” Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with lisinopril and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. On exam, the patient is alert with mild word-finding difficulty and is unable to write. Sensory and motor exams are normal. Which additional symptom would most likely confirm the location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
This 49-year-old patient presents with symptoms consistent with Gerstmann syndrome, including agraphia, left-right disorientation, and possible finger agnosia. These findings are commonly associated with lesions of the left angular gyrus. Acalculia, another hallmark of Gerstmann syndrome, may be identified by asking the patient to complete simple arithmetic tasks.        

The clinical presentation of cortical lesions varies based on the location of involvement. Dominant symptoms help narrow the differential diagnosis: aphasia (impaired speech production or comprehension), anopsia (visual field deficits), agnosia (inability to recognize objects, people, or stimuli despite intact sensory function), or neglect. In contrast, subcortical lesions often manifest as motor abnormalities (e.g., weakness, involuntary movements), hemisensory loss, or cognitive and behavioral changes (e.g., memory impairment, apathy, hypersexuality, hyperphagia).        

When a cortical lesion presents with agnosia, it is important to identify the specific type. Finger agnosia (inability to distinguish or recognize one’s fingers), along with acalculia, agraphia, and left-right disorientation, suggests a lesion in the dominant (typically left) angular gyrus. In contrast, prosopagnosia (inability to recognize familiar faces) is associated with bilateral lesions of the fusiform gyri in the occipitotemporal region.   

Option Analysis

✅ Inability to perform calculations:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inability to recognize faces :
Incorrect: Prosopagnosia, or the inability to recognize familiar faces, is typically associated with lesions of the bilateral fusiform gyri. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can produce Gerstmann syndrome, a condition that may also feature acalculia. 
❌ Hemiballismus:
Incorrect: Hemiballismus can be seen in basal ganglia lesions. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can produce Gerstmann syndrome, a condition that may also feature acalculia. 
❌ Hyperphagia:
Incorrect: Hyperphagia, often accompanied by hyperorality and visual agnosia, is a feature of Kluver-Bucy syndrome, which results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can pr
❌ Impaired delayed recall:
Incorrect: Impaired delayed recall is a finding more consistent with lesions affecting the hippocampus. This patient’s symptoms support a lesion in the left angular gyrus, which can produce Gerstmann syndrome, a condition that may also feature acalculia.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the primary care clinic by a family member for evaluation of confusion. Over the past week, the patient has become unable to recognize familiar faces but can identify family members by voice and mannerisms. There has been no fever, but the patient reports vertigo described as dizziness and has experienced several falls. Medical history is notable for small cell lung cancer with known metastases to both adrenal glands. The patient is not currently receiving treatment and takes no medications. There is no alcohol or substance use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. On examination, there is mild right-sided weakness and dysarthria, with an inability to recognize famous faces. Which of the following diagnostic tests would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with contrast
Computerized tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast

questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with agnosia, specifically prosopagnosia, which is the inability to recognize faces. This is a cortical sign that localizes to the bilateral fusiform gyri. Given her known cancer diagnosis, the most helpful test to confirm a suspected metastatic lesion is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with intravenous contrast.       

Patients with cortical lesions exhibit symptoms based on the region of the brain involved. The differential diagnosis can often be narrowed by the dominant presenting symptom, such as aphasia, anopsia, agnosia, or neglect. On the other hand, subcortical lesions typically present with motor symptoms, hemisensory loss, or cognitive and behavioral changes. When agnosia is the primary symptom, it is important to identify the specific type. The combination of finger agnosia, acalculia, agraphia, and left-right disorientation suggests a lesion in the dominant (usually left) angular gyrus. In contrast, prosopagnosia is associated with bilateral lesions of the fusiform gyri in the occipitotemporal region.       

Neuroimaging is essential for confirming the diagnosis. MRI, with and without intravenous contrast, can help characterize the lesion and differentiate between potential causes.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast:
Incorrect: CT without contrast has limited sensitivity for detecting cortical or posterior fossa lesions, especially in the setting of subacute neurologic symptoms. MRI with contrast provides superior visualization of potential metastases or paraneoplastic processes affecting the temporal or occipital lobes. 
❌ Neuropsychological testing:
Incorrect: While neuropsychological testing can characterize cognitive deficits, it is not the initial diagnostic step in the evaluation of acute-onset prosopagnosia and focal neurologic findings. Structural imaging is required to assess for metastatic or other brain lesions. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the chest:
Incorrect: The primary malignancy has already been diagnosed. Evaluation should focus on the current neurologic symptoms, which raise concern for brain metastases. 
❌ Sputum cytology:
Incorrect: Cytology is used to establish a primary lung cancer diagnosis but is not useful in a patient with already diagnosed small cell lung cancer. Given the acute neurologic findings, brain imaging is the appropriate next step.

questions.text: A 21-year-old nonbinary athlete is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of paralysis. The patient was playing football and collided helmet-to-helmet with an opposing player. Immediate collapse followed, with the inability to move their arms or legs and loss of sensation in all extremities. Past medical history is noncontributory, and no medications are taken. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on 10 L via non-rebreather mask. On examination, the patient is alert, anxious, and able to speak in full sentences. There is no spontaneous movement of the extremities, and no withdrawal to painful stimuli. Central and peripheral pulses are 2+ throughout. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the cervical spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute cervical spinal cord injury, evidenced by flaccid paralysis and loss of sensation in both the upper and lower extremities. This patient exhibits hypopnea and hypoxia, indicating impending respiratory failure, for which intubation and mechanical ventilation are indicated.       

Acute management of a spinal cord injury begins with an ABCDE assessment and stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. High cervical lesions may impair diaphragmatic function due to involvement of the C3, C4, and C5 nerve roots, which innervate the diaphragm. In such cases, respiratory failure may necessitate prompt intubation and ventilatory support.       

All patients should have intravenous access established, along with continuous vital sign monitoring and cardiac telemetry. Lesions above the level of T6 can disrupt sympathetic innervation to the heart and peripheral vasculature, leading to unopposed parasympathetic activity via the vagus nerve. This may result in neurogenic shock, characterized by bradycardia and hypotension. Management of neurogenic shock includes intravenous fluid resuscitation and, when necessary, vasopressor support for refractory hypotension.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) lorazepam:
Incorrect: Although lorazepam may be used for acute anxiety, it is not appropriate in this context. This patient exhibits signs of respiratory compromise and impending failure following cervical spinal cord trauma. Administration of sedatives may further depress respiratory drive. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the cervical spine:
Incorrect: While CT is the preferred initial imaging modality to evaluate for cervical spine fractures, this patient requires urgent airway management prior to diagnostic studies due to signs of respiratory compromise. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine:
Incorrect: MRI can help assess spinal cord integrity, but it should be performed only after the airway is secured. This patient shows evidence of high cervical cord injury with respiratory insufficiency, requiring immediate ventilatory support. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) isotonic crystalloid fluid bolus:
Incorrect: Neurogenic shock from cervical spinal cord injury may necessitate fluid resuscitation, but this patient's blood pressure and perfusion are currently stable. Respiratory failure remains the more urgent concern.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of difficulty speaking. The patient was dining with a friend when she suddenly could not find words to continue the story she was telling. Past medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include lisinopril, metformin, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 188/98 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears alert and anxious, saying phrases like, “Friend tea today” and “Speak trouble.” The patient can follow written directions but cannot write. There is drift in the right arm. Which additional test is key to differentiating the location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of expressive aphasia, including short, poorly formed sentences, word-finding difficulty, and non-fluent speech with improper grammar. To distinguish between Broca and transcortical motor aphasia, ask the patient to repeat words or phrases.       

Assessment of the type of aphasia can help you localize the lesion. There are four types of aphasia: expressive, receptive, conduction, and global. While all will present with communication difficulties, each will differ in terms of speech production. An important physical examination maneuver is to ask the patient to repeat words or phrases. If the patient cannot repeat, the differential diagnosis includes global aphasia, conduction aphasia, Wernicke receptive aphasia, and Broca expressive aphasia. If the patient can repeat, the differential diagnosis includes transcortical motor or sensory aphasia.         

Another important physical examination maneuver is to ask the patient to read and write words and phrases. Patients with expressive aphasia will display intact reading skills but will struggle with writing, while those with receptive aphasia will be unable to read or write.    


Option Analysis

✅ Repetition of words and phrases:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Orientation questions :
Incorrect: Orientation questions assess awareness of time, place, and person, but they are not particularly useful for localizing aphasia. This patient is alert, and the phrases spoken do not suggest disorientation. The ability to repeat phrases, however, could help differentiate between Broca aphasia and transcortical motor aphasia.  
❌ Visual field assessment:
Incorrect: Visual field testing is an important component of the neurological examination and can indicate damage to the occipital lobe or optic pathways. However, aphasia is more likely related to dysfunction in the frontal or temporal lobes, which are involved in language processing. Testing for repetition of words and phrases is more specific for localizing the lesion within the language network.  
❌ Finger-to-nose test:
Incorrect: The finger-to-nose test evaluates cerebellar function and is used to assess for dysmetria. However, aphasia is more likely related to dysfunction in the frontal or temporal lobes, which are involved in language processing. Testing for repetition of words and phrases is more specific for localizing the lesion within the language network.  
❌ Reading aloud:
Incorrect: Reading aloud assesses fluency and comprehension in the context of language function. However, it does not provide additional information in this case since the patient has already demonstrated non-fluent language and the preserved ability to read.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. Over the past two months, the patient has become increasingly withdrawn, exhibiting confusion, memory loss, and a noticeable reduction in both speech and movement. Recently, the patient has not spoken at all and has developed intermittent, quick jerks of the bilateral upper extremities. Past medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux managed with omeprazole. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Liver, kidney, and thyroid function tests are normal, and a urine toxicology screen is negative. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows cortical ribboning on diffusion-weighted imaging sequences, and continuous video electroencephalography (EEG) shows periodic sharp wave complexes. Which of the following additional tests is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of these symptoms?

choices.text: Total serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels

questions.solution:
This patient presents with subacute encephalopathy, including progressive cognitive decline, akinetic mutism, and myoclonus, in the context of normal metabolic studies and abnormal MRI findings showing cortical ribboning and EEG with periodic sharp wave complexes. These findings are characteristic of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). To confirm the diagnosis, advanced cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis should be performed, including 14-3-3 protein testing and RT-QuIC assay, which detects misfolded prions.

Encephalopathy can result from a variety of causes, including neurologic and medical conditions. If initial laboratory, neurophysiologic, and neuroimaging studies are unremarkable, additional neurodiagnostic tests based on the patient’s symptoms can help identify the underlying cause and direct further treatment.

Patients with chronic alcohol use or severe malnutrition can develop Wernicke encephalopathy. Young individuals, especially female patients, with abrupt behavioral changes and a movement disorder should have CSF analysis for possible NMDA-receptor antibody encephalitis. Adults with rapidly worsening confusion, decreased spontaneous movements, and myoclonus should undergo CSF analysis for 14-3-3 protein or an RT-QuIC assay to confirm Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Total serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels:
Incorrect: While Wilson disease, a genetic disorder causing copper accumulation, can present with symptoms of encephalopathy and abnormal movements, the neuroimaging and neurophysiological findings in this case are more consistent with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). CSF analysis is needed for confirmation.
❌ Serum ethanol level:
Incorrect: While chronic alcohol use can cause encephalopathy and abnormal movements, the neuroimaging and neurophysiological findings in this case are more consistent with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). CSF analysis is needed for confirmation.
❌ Mammography:
Incorrect: While metastases from a primary breast cancer could cause encephalopathy and abnormal movements, the neuroimaging and neurophysiological findings in this case are more consistent with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). CSF analysis is needed for confirmation.
❌ Genetic epilepsy panel:
Incorrect: While periodic sharp wave complexes can be seen in certain cases of epilepsy, particularly in patients presenting in status epilepticus, the neuroimaging findings in this case are more consistent with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). CSF analysis is needed for confirmation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of headache. For the past week, the patient’s head pain has been gradually intensifying and worsens with coughing or straining during a bowel movement. Nausea is present, along with several episodes of nonbilious emesis today. Blurry vision is noted bilaterally. Past medical history is noncontributory aside from a recent episode of a right otitis media for which oral amoxicillin was prescribed. However, the course was not completed due to nausea.
